title: CVPR_1994_10_abs

sentences.text: MINPRAN , a new robust operator , nds good ts in data sets where more than 50 % of the points are outliers .
Unlike other techniques that handle large outlier percentages , MINPRAN does not rely on a known error bound for the good data .
Instead it assumes that the bad data are randomly -LRB- uniformly -RRB- distributed within the dynamic range of the sensor .
Based on this , MINPRAN uses random sampling to search for the t and the number of inliers to the t that are least likely to have occurred randomly .
It runs in time O -LRB- N 2 + SN log N -RRB- , where S is the number of random samples and N is the number of data points .

We demonstrate analytically that MINPRAN distinguishes good ts from ts to random data , and that MINPRAN nds accurate ts and nearly the correct number of inliers , regardless of the percentage of true inliers .
MINPRAN 's properties are connrmed experimentally on synthetic data and compare favorably to least median of squares .
Related work applies MINPRAN to complex range and intensity data 23 -RSB- .

Entity-the_bad_data.label: the bad data
Entity-the_bad_data.description: Data points that are assumed to be randomly and uniformly distributed within the dynamic range of a sensor, which are considered outliers or 'bad data' in the context of robust operator MINPRAN.

Entity-t_from_t_to_random_data.label: ts from ts to random data
aliases: ts from ts to random data
Entity-t_from_t_to_random_data.description: The ability of MINPRAN to distinguish between good time stamps (ts) and those that are randomly generated from random data.

Entity-minpran.label: MINPRAN
Entity-minpran.description: A novel algorithm that finds accurate transformations and nearly correct numbers of inliers even when over half of the data points are outliers.

Entity-s_property.description: The characteristics or attributes that define MINPRAN, a robust operator for handling large outlier percentages in data sets.

Entity-a_new_robust_operator.description: A novel algorithm that detects accurate thresholds and nearly correct numbers of inliers in datasets with a high percentage of outliers, without relying on known error bounds.

Entity-large_outlier_percentage.description: The percentage of outliers in a dataset that exceeds a typical threshold (e.g., more than 50%), which requires robust operators like MINPRAN to handle effectively.

summary: MINPRAN , a new robust operator , nds good ts in data sets where more than 50 % of the points are outliers . Unlike other techniques that handle large outlier percentages , MINPRAN does not rely on a known error bound for the good data . Instead it assumes that the bad data are randomly -LRB- uniformly -RRB- distributed within the dynamic range of the sensor . Based on this , MINPRAN uses random sampling to search for the t and the number of inliers to the t that are least likely to have occurred randomly . It runs in time O -LRB- N 2 + SN log N -RRB- , where S is the number of random samples and N is the number of data points . We demonstrate analytically that MINPRAN distinguishes good ts from ts to random data , and that MINPRAN nds accurate ts and nearly the correct number of inliers , regardless of the percentage of true inliers . MINPRAN 's properties are connrmed experimentally on synthetic data and compare favorably to least median of squares . Related work applies MINPRAN to complex range and intensity data 23 -RSB- .

Predicate-are.label: are
Predicate-are.description: The predicate 'are' indicates a relationship between the subject and object in which the subject possesses or consists of the qualities described by the object. It can be used to describe inherent properties, classifications, or categorizations.

Predicate-distinguishes_good_ts_from_ts_.label: distinguishes good ts from ts to random data
Predicate-distinguishes_good_ts_from_ts_.description: This predicate connects a subject (e.g. an algorithm or model) that evaluates and separates 'good' time series signals ('ts') from those that are randomly generated, indicating its ability to discern meaningful patterns from noise.

Predicate-handles.label: handles
Predicate-handles.description: The predicate 'handles' indicates a relationship where the subject has control or management over the object. It suggests that the subject is responsible for dealing with, coping with, or taking care of the object's characteristics, properties, or effects.

Predicate-uses.label: uses
Predicate-uses.description: The predicate 'uses' indicates a relationship where the subject (an entity or process) employs or utilizes the object (a method, technique, tool, etc.) to achieve some purpose or goal.

Predicate-searches_for.label: searches for
Predicate-searches_for.description: The predicate 'searches for' indicates that the subject (an entity or individual) actively seeks out and attempts to find or locate the object. This connection implies a sense of inquiry, investigation, or pursuit, suggesting that the subject has some level of interest or motivation in discovering the object.

Predicate-distinguishes.label: distinguishes
Predicate-distinguishes.description: The predicate 'distinguishes' connects a subject (e.g., MINPRAN) with an object that represents a distinction or separation, indicating that the subject has the ability to differentiate between two or more entities, concepts, or categories. In general, it implies a process of discernment, classification, or identification.

Predicate-nds.label: nds
Predicate-nds.description: The predicate 'nds' indicates a relationship where the subject has some degree of similarity or approximation to the object. The connection between the subject and object suggests that there may be a shared characteristic, attribute, or quality that makes them comparable in some way.

Predicate-have.label: have
Predicate-have.description: The predicate 'have' indicates a relationship of possession or ownership between the subject and object. It suggests that the subject has control over, responsibility for, or is associated with the properties mentioned as the object.

Predicate-compare_favorably_to.label: compare favorably to
Predicate-compare_favorably_to.description: The predicate 'compare favorably to' indicates a relationship where the subject and object are being evaluated against each other. The comparison suggests that the subject has similar or better qualities, characteristics, or attributes compared to those of the object.

Predicate-applies.label: applies
Predicate-applies.description: The predicate 'applies' indicates a relationship where the subject (a concept or idea) has relevance, pertinence, or effectiveness to the object (another concept, method, framework, etc.). It suggests that the subject can be used, employed, or utilized in some way with respect to the object.

Predicate-to.label: to
Predicate-to.description: The predicate 'to' indicates a relationship of correspondence or equivalence between two entities. It suggests that the subject and object are connected by sharing similar characteristics, properties, or attributes.

Predicate-applies_to_complex_range_and_i.label: applies to complex range and intensity data
Predicate-applies_to_complex_range_and_i.description: This predicate indicates that a subject (e.g., an algorithm or model) has relevance or applicability to datasets containing complex range and intensity values, such as those found in medical imaging, audio processing, or other fields where nuanced spatial or temporal patterns are present. The connection between the subject and object is one of functional association, implying that the subject can operate on, analyze, or make predictions about data with these characteristics.

Predicate-assumes.label: assumes
Predicate-assumes.description: The predicate 'assumes' indicates that the subject takes something as true or given without necessarily verifying its accuracy. It implies a mental attitude of acceptance and reliance on the object, which can be an idea, concept, data, or situation.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' indicates that the subject is related to or encompasses the object as a more general category. It suggests a hierarchical relationship between the two entities, where the subject represents a higher-level concept and the object represents a lower-level instance or subclass.
